headline: Leny Yoro deal shows Sir Jim Ratcliffe has kept his promise on Manchester United transfers
body: Man Utd are set to sign an 18-year-old centre-back who was wanted by Real Madrid and the deal is a major milestone for Ineos.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Sir Jim Ratcliffe didn't shy away from the biggest issue that has held Manchester United back when he completed his £1.25bn deal to invest in the club in February.

"I think recruitment in the modern game is critical. Manchester United have clearly spent a lot of money but they haven't done as well as some other clubs," Ratcliffe said in his first sit-down interview as the club's minority owner.
"So when I was talking about being best-in-class in all aspects of football, recruitment is probably top of the list."

The 71-year-old has never really hid his feelings about the transfer operation at Old Trafford. A few years ago he called United the "dumb money" in football and a look at the rewards for the £1.6bn spend since 2013 would make that a fair assessment.

In recent months he has touched again on recruitment. He told the Geraint Thomas Cycling Club podcast that "the solution isn’t spending a lot of money on a couple of great players", and then said he wanted to sign the next Kylian Mbappe rather than the man himself.

The extent to which Ratcliffe has placed recruitment at the top of the list in areas to improve can be seen in the overhaul of roles at Old Trafford. Since February, Ineos have appointed Dan Ashworth as sporting director, Jason Wilcox as technical director and Christopher Vivell as interim director of recruitment. Three executives with vast experience in transfers and a reputation as shrewd operators.

They are making a good start as well. The deal for Joshua Zirkzee was wrapped up quickly after his involvement in Euro 2024 came to an end, with a deal agreed with Bologna that helped United navigate their own financial concerns. But it is the second transfer of the summer that looks set to cause a storm.

When United had a bid accepted by Lille for 18-year-old Leny Yoro recently there still wasn't a feeling it was going to happen. The teenager is out of contract next summer so held the ace cards and it had long been expected that he wanted to move to Real Madrid.

But United's aggressive approach in making an offer Lille clearly couldn't refuse tilted the balance and they have convinced him his future can be at Old Trafford. At an initial £52m it is a large fee, rising to £58.7m with add-ons, but that remains well below what Everton want for Jarrad Branthwaite. Yoro has far more high-level exposure at this stage of his career than Branthwaite had at 18, when he spent time on loan at Blackburn and played 10 games in the Championship.

Yoro has already racked up 46 appearances in Ligue 1 and is probably the most highly-rated young centre-back in Europe. The fact he made the Ligue 1 team of the year speaks of his talent and he doesn't turn 19 until November. He could be a United centre-back for years to come.

The deal would certainly be a feather in the cap for Ineos and particularly for Ashworth, Wilcox and Vivell. Convincing Yoro to put aside his ambitions to play for Real Madrid is a significant achievement and he has clearly been sold on the idea of progressing his career at Old Trafford.

They have also acted decisively. Yoro's move to Real had looked like a formality, but while the European champions waited to play hardball over a fee, United stepped in. It is an example of the quick-thinking and nimbleness that Ratcliffe would want the club to show.
There is more work to be in this window, but in a significant couple of months for Ineos they are laying down a marker already.

Zirkzee's move to Manchester from Italy was confirmed for €42.5million last weekend and the striker is expected to join up with the squad in early August after a summer break.
The 23-year-old earned a late call-up to the Netherlands squad for Euro 2024 and his nation reached the semi-finals of the tournament, hence why he'll link up at a later date.

United prioritised strengthening their attacking options in this summer transfer window and Zirkzee, who finished last season as Bolgona's top goalscorer with league 11 goals, was identified as someone who could add quality to the attack and compete with Hojlund to start.
Zirkzee's first interview with club media was released on Wednesday afternoon and the player has also spoken to Dutch YouTube show Matchday since signing.

When discussing his transfer to United, Zirkzee said conversations intensified while he was in Germany for Euro 2024: "I had a conversation in Wolfsburg. My father was there too because he is there for everything. After that conversation, I immediately had a good feeling.
"Then the choice was actually already made. The European Championship was number one anyway, United also thought that was important. That was where the focus had to be. So that was doable."
Zirkzee's shirt number hasn't been confirmed by United, but he is an incredibly laidback character and admitted he is relaxed about which number he's given in the new season.

Anthony Martial departed United on a free transfer this summer and vacated the No.9 shirt, which Zirkzee expects Hojlund to take. "That depends a bit on Rasmus Hojlund. He's already there and he's also a striker," he said when asked whether he knew his shirt number.
"No.9 is free, but yeah... He has 11, so I can imagine that he wants No.9 now. In that case I'll take 11. At Bologna I also had 11, so that doesn't really matter to me."
Bologna defied the odds to finish in the Italian top four last term. They enjoyed their best season since 1967/1968 and Zirkzee started 32 out of a possible 38 league games.

headline: Manchester United might copy Pep Guardiola tactic and spring Leny Yoro surprise
body: Leny Yoro is closing in on a move to Man United and could be used in a different defensive role to his natural position.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Manchester United fans will admit Pep Guardiola has been at the forefront of evolving tactics.

Guardiola made playing false nines fashionable, he introduced playing out from the back to England and, more recently, began to play central defenders in full-back roles. Other managers have followed Guardiola's tactical innovations and his former assistant manager Mikel Arteta picked up the central defender idea and ran with it at the Emirates.

Arteta has played Ben White out of position and Guardiola has changed the roles of Nathan Ake and Josko Gvardiol, with all three of those regularly playing as full-backs last season, providing extra defensive solidity on the wings and an advantage in build-up play.

Centre backs tend to be significantly better one-on-one defenders than traditional full-backs and that's an obvious positive, but playing a natural centre half as a full-back also allows teams to have a back-three in build-up, which helps to press high and defend counter-attacks.

Playing central defenders out of position became a popular trend last season and Liverpool and Aston Villa played Joe Gomez and Ezri Konsa as their full-backs respectively. The four teams who finished at the top Premier League all used the innovation, which suggests there's an advantage in doing so if implemented correctly.

Now enter United and Erik ten Hag, who has often instructed his full-backs to play an inverted role, which is why Diogo Dalot comes into midfield from the right. Perhaps Ten Hag is happy with his current system and believes it doesn't need to be tweaked, but an elite manager adapts to the players at his disposal and the United squad is changing this summer, with Leny Yoro coming in and Aaron Wan-Bissaka expected to leave.

Wan-Bissaka has entered the final year of his contract and selling him this summer is the last opportunity to recoup a decent fee for someone who was signed for £50m in the summer of 2019, with West Ham said to be interested.

Although moving on Wan-Bissaka would leave Dalot as the only senior right-back in the squad, Yoro is flying to Manchester for a medical and is an option in that role. Yoro is a natural centre-back and made 44 appearances at the heart of Lille's defence last season, but starting in central defence at just 18 years old in the Premier League is bound to be a tough challenge and he could be eased into the team at right-back.

Like every player at his age, Yoro needs time to physically develop and playing him at right-back would allow him to improve and gain experience without coming under the cosh in central defence. As the last line of defence, centre-backs are exposed and tested by the opposition more than any other outfield players and Yoro might not be ready for that challenge.

He is a defender for the future - United hope he'll become one of the world's best - but immediately chucking him into the deep end is inadvisable. Yoro has the qualities to excel at right-back for United.

It might not be a position Yoro has played before, but he's comfortable with the ball at his feet, he intelligently reads the game and his natural athleticism will help him adapt. His long-term future is in the middle but it wouldn't be a surprise to see him at right-back this season.

headline: Manchester United handed Leny Yoro decision amid Lisandro Martinez concern
body: Lisandro Martinez has played only 38 matches in the Premier League across two seasons due to various injury setbacks since his €57million transfer from Ajax.

Manchester United are working around the clock to bolster their defensive options for next season with as many as three centre-back signings in the offing. Leny Yoro is set to be first through the door at Old Trafford after a deal worth £52million - potentially rising to £58.7million with add-ons - was agreed.

The highly-rated French teenager is for the present and future - depending on what other business United do - as Erik ten Hag also contemplates how to tackle a familiar problem. Matthijs de Ligt and Everton's Jarrad Branthwaite are the other two fixed targets on radar for Ten Hag and INEOS behind the scenes.
Further additions will be dependent on outgoings. However, in the scenario by which De Ligt and Branthwaite do join as well, there will be growing concern for Lisandro Martinez.

There are countless attributes that Martinez brings to the table - too many to mention - but the fan favourite has not been available for selection anywhere near as much as United would have wanted since he pitched up at Old Trafford from Ajax two years ago. He has totted-up 38 games in the Premier League across those two seasons and the drop-off in quality when he has been missing has been stark.

United were hit as hard as anyone when it came to injuries last season and that hoodoo particularly affected the defensive options available to them. England regular Luke Shaw was sorely missed at left-back - returning only in time for that Euro 2024 showpiece - while Martinez also proved to be irreplaceable.

A huge tick for Ten Hag in the market before the keys to recruitment were snatched away from the Dutchman by INEOS this summer, there is no doubt Martinez has the quality to shine on the Premier League stage, even though the 25-year-old had to silence the outside noise, mainly regarding his size.

As things stand, Martinez, who has yet to report back to Carrington for pre-season after Copa America glory with Argentina, will start for United when fit, even with Yoro through the door. However, with De Ligt and Branthwaite on board - however fanciful that might seem - game-time would have to be taken away from someone.

Of course, competition and cover is fundamental for any successful squad, but Martinez would be at risk through previous concerns, while how much United expose Yoro, 18, in the early days will be dependent on who else they sign. Still, that will be infinitely more welcome the fitness woes United had to deal with last season.

headline: Erik ten Hag sounding like Jose Mourinho in pre-season is good for Manchester United
body: 'Good is not good enough' was Erik ten Hag's maxim in his first season at Man United. It wasn't last season but he is sounding like his old self.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Fear and loathing in Los Angeles? Manchester United return to UCLA next week six years on from the tour de farce that signalled the beginning of the end for Jose Mourinho.

Mourinho was in a lugubrious mood but deprived of support. Rui Faria was no longer by his side, Ed Woodward was dodging him, United were devoid of a director of communications and their World Cup participants were on holiday.

To compound that, Woodward was struggling to recruit a centre back and a winger. After United's last friendly against Bayern Munich, a smiling Mourinho told MUTV: "Finally, it's over. Our pre-season is over."

Following the final tour match against Real Madrid, Mourinho held an encore at the Hard Rock Stadium in Miami, reminding his audience United's under 23s were relegated the previous season and their "quality was not good".
Some survivors of that team were about to board the United bus for Miami airport. Mourinho threw them under it.

It struck a portentous tone but Mourinho was right. The five-game tour was a largely meaningless excursion and those experiences have doubtless had a bearing on United trimming their Stateside commitments to three games this summer.

For the opening friendly in Trondheim on Monday, MUTV struggled to maintain its North Korea standards. Ronny Johnsen, the United ambassador-cum-pundit, went off-message when he noted how "quiet" it was at the Lerkendal Stadion.
When Erik ten Hag sidled over for a post-match debrief, the presenter informed him the "result is secondary". "The result is not secondary," Ten Hag corrected him.
Ten Hag stressed United were "not good enough", the "performance was below the standards" and "this is not the standard for top football".
United did not have top players. Of the 25 in Trondheim, only Jonny Evans and Mason Mount are certain to be in the squad next season. Evans has earned that privilege. Mount hasn't.

Videographers are all the rage now among Gen Z footballers and one charted Hannibal Mejbri's workout during his holiday. Mejbri promised a "special season". There was nothing special about his performance.
Mejbri was busy off the ball and ineffectual on it, as he was during his four starts last season. Rosenborg are 14 games into the Norwegian campaign but they are also 11th in a 16-team league.

United's best player was a lad who had never appeared for the first team before. United's goal led a charmed life as Rosenborg struck the woodwork four times and Radek Vitek pulled off two world-class saves either side of the interval.
"Let's say he (Vitek) got the opportunity from the team to make some very good saves," Ten Hag shrugged. His negative analysis has been buried on the club website.

Ten Hag, like Mourinho six years ago, is into his third pre-season as United manager and not mincing his words. It was jarring that he could be so positive in defeat last season having been constructively critical in victory during his first term.

Some may feel Ten Hag went overboard over a perfunctory friendly. United have headed to Norway in five of their last seven proper pre-season schedules and invariably it has not been worth their while.

There was a spiky defeat to Atletico Madrid two years ago and Kobbie Mainoo imposed himself during a 45-minute run-out against Leeds last year. There was little to write home about from playing against Valerenga, Kristiansund and Rosenborg. The latter two 1-0s were settled by goals in added time.

The standard of opposition was not the issue on Monday as Rosenborg were enterprising and intense. Too many in red went through the motions. United were marginally better in the second half with an academy XI.

Two of their starters were Champions League winners, three had World Cup experience and five have started in FA Cup finals. United's only attempt on target in the first half was from the 18-year-old Ethan Wheatley, a rare bright spark.

Ten Hag could have dismissed the result and the performance yet this is a team that plummeted to eighth in the Premier League last season and collected the wooden spoon in their Champions League group. Even MUTV has to host some home truths.
United will field a stronger side against Rangers in Edinburgh on Saturday and possibly a more senior XI a week later against Arsenal in Los Angeles.
That should quell any fear and loathing.

headline: Erik ten Hag gesture hints at chance for Manchester United youngster to solve problem position
body: Man Utd need a defensive midfielder to come through the ranks and they could have one in the making after a bright debut in Trondheim for Toby Collyer.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info

When Casemiro took off the captain's armband in the away dressing room at Lerkendal and strapped it onto Toby Collyer's bicep, the symbolism would have hung heavy in the air. This wasn't a changing of the guard just yet, but Manchester United's two captains on the night hinted at careers going in different directions.

For Casemiro, this was the kind of start to pre-season he didn't want. It's perhaps a little surprising the 32-year-old is still around, but interest from Saudi Arabia hasn't emerged and as it stands he looks likely to see through a third campaign in Manchester. He needs the snap to return to his game.

His last competitive involvement was pulling out of the FA Cup final squad between the teamsheets being submitted and then confirmed. He was due to be a substitute at Wembley but felt tightness and withdrew. It summed up a season in which he looked and played like a veteran entering the twilight of his career.

The Brazilian doesn't turn 33 until February but has had a demanding career in Europe and has a build that suggests fitness doesn't always come easily to him. He was a weak link in United's midfield for much of last season, although the open nature of that department didn't exactly offer him much protection.

Maybe he will be better in a smarter system this term and against Rosenborg there were a couple of nice passes, but he fell over scuffing a clearance in his box and was pounced on and lost possession just outside the area. It was an inauspicious start for a player who will want to prove the career obituaries are being penned too early.
It was certainly a contrast to Collyer, who strode onto the pitch with his socks rolled low, looking more of a throwback than the man he had replaced. But he played like a modern No.6.

His former Brighton Under-18s coach Mark Beard once labelled him the best defensive midfielder in the country for his age. He is a month older than Adam Wharton, who has excelled for first-team exposure and was part of England's Euro 2024 squad, although he didn't kick a ball.

Until Monday night, the closest Collyer had come to playing on a big stage was in the academy friendly against Wrexham in San Diego a year ago. This was a bigger night than that and he looked the part in a callow second-half side.

He was combative and strong in the tackle, took up intelligent positions to block attacks and used the ball well, happy to receive it from the defence or goalkeeper Radek Vitek and try and keep it moving forward. One flick on the left touchline to the advancing Harry Amass was a stylish contribution.

Collyer recently signed a new four-year contract at Old Trafford and although he hasn't yet played for the first team, Erik ten Hag insisted on being present for the signing of the paperwork. This is a player he rates highly, as seen by the decision to give him the captaincy for the second half on Monday night.

He will get further chances this summer as well. Collyer is expected to go on the pre-season tour to the United States, with Scott McTominay and Christian Eriksen returning from their summer breaks to boost options in midfield. Ten Hag has urged the youngsters involved in pre-season to take their opportunity, just as Kobbie Mainoo did a year ago. Collyer could be the biggest beneficiary of more first-team exposure.

He plays in a position that United have struggled to fill for a long time now. Casemiro looked to be the answer in his first season but the £70m signing now has questions to answer. There is still a chance United sell and look to sign a younger player in that position during this window.

Sofyan Amrabat contributed last season and United still haven't decided whether to try and sign the 27-year-old on a permanent deal, though the player is keen to return to Old Trafford. Amrabat isn't good enough in possession and it would be a retrograde step, while Ten Hag has decided McTominay is best utilised further forward and there is interest again in the Scot this summer.

It's expecting too much for Collyer to force his way into the starting XI for the opening day of the league campaign, but he could emerge as a rotation option this season. If Casemiro does go a replacement will be signed, but with a little more experience under his belt, Collyer could become a first-team option in a position where United really need a succession plan.

Ten Hag went on record to express his frustration at injuries in that area and many fans believe United should sign a new left-back in the summer transfer window. Malacia was on crutches after his initial injury and spent some time in the Netherlands to recover, and a source indicated he was expected to return before 2024.

Kobbie Mainoo has sent his best wishes to Willy Kambwala following confirmation of the young defender's transfer to Villarreal.

Kambwala, who made his first-team debut for Manchester United against West Ham in the Premier League last season, racked up eight league appearances and featured twice in the FA Cup. He now heads to Spain in a deal that could reach £9.6 million.

The departure of the ex-Sochaux talent marks the second paid exit from United this summer, with Donny van de Beek earlier moving to Girona for an initial fee of £500,000 plus add-ons. This figure is notably less than the £35 million United spent to bring him from Ajax in 2020.

Mainoo, who played alongside Kambwala in the UEFA Youth League before establishing himself in the senior squad, expressed his support on social media, commenting "Big love bro, all the best," on Kambwala's Instagram post announcing his move.

Kambwala shared his gratitude and reflections on his time at United: "Dear @manchesterunited, I arrived at the club as a boy with a dream and today I'm leaving like a young man who has fulfilled his dream," he posted. "From the academy to the first team, it's time for me to start a new adventure after 4 wonderful seasons at the club".

He continued, acknowledging those who supported him during his journey: "Thank you to all the people I have met during these 4 years. Coaches, my teammates, staff members, workers in Carrington and members of my host family."
"I'll never forget what you all did for me. A special thank you to you fans who have always supported me, you are the soul of this club. I wish you the best for this season and for the future."

United have inserted a buy-back option into Kambwala's deal, as well as a significant sell-on clause. The 19 year old joins former Old Trafford star Eric Bailly at his new club, as well as several other former Premier League men including Alexander Sorloth and Juan Foyth.

Mainoo wasn't the other United academy talent to wish the defender well. Joe Hugill, Dan Gore and Maxi Oyedele all shared messages of support, as did Toby Collyer, who recently signed a new contract at Old Trafford.

Ethan Wheatley also shared a message for Kambwala, and the young striker was among those to get minutes for United in their first pre-season match against Rosenborg on Monday. The Norwegian side won 1-0 thanks to a late goal from Noah Holm, and manager Erik ten Hag demanded better from his players after senior stars including Marcus Rashford and Casemiro joined a squad primarily made up of youngsters.
"The result is not secondary," Ten Hag said. "Our performance as a team is by far not good enough. This is not the standard of top football. We are Man Utd, we should perform better".

headline: Yoro, Branthwaite and De Ligt sign - Manchester United's perfect £150m transfer window simulated
body: We simulated the 2024/25 season with Jarrad Branthwaite, Matthijs de Ligt and Leny Yoro all at Man United to see what could happen

Manchester United have made moves for defenders Jarrad Branthwaite, Matthijs de Ligt and Leny Yoro this summer, but what could happen if all three signed?

Personal terms have been agreed with De Ligt while Yoro has agreed to join the club despite interest from Real Madrid. A deal could still be done for Branthwaite after United's first two bids were rejected.
But if United were to have the perfect summer transfer window and all three defenders signed, how could they fare next season? Let's take a look...

To set up this simulation, we used Football Manager 2024 to move the defensive trio to United in the summer transfer window for a combined fee of £150million. We then simulated the 2024/25 season, and this is how the defenders got on.

Ten Hag was keen to play his new additions as much as possible, with the Dutchman eventually deciding to move Lisandro Martinez into midfield to accommodate his signings. This worked a treat, with all three defenders playing regularly in their first season at the club.

De Ligt and Branthwaite was the partnership that saw the most game time in the simulation, with the latter making 41 appearances, one more than De Ligt. As the least experienced, Yoro was eased into the squad, but in his 28 appearances the Frenchman averaged a rating of 7.03 per game along with five assists - the same rating as De Ligt, and higher than Branthwaite (6.98).
At the end of the 2024/25 season, Football Manager 2024 put together an overall best United XI, based on performances, statistics, and other metrics. This is what it looked like:
Full United best XI: (4-3-3):  Onana; Dalot, De Ligt, Branthwaite, Shaw; Martinez, Fernandes, Mainoo; Garnacho, Hojlund, Rashford.

De Ligt and Branthwaite were the centre-back partnership in the best XI, with Yoro missing out. Martinez made the best XI as a holding midfielder, with Bruno Fernandes and Kobbie Mainoo completing the midfield three.

New signing Joshua Zirkzee failed to make the best XI with Rasmus Hojlund scoring more goals than the Dutchman. Both Maguire and Lindelof were sold in the simulation, leaving little competition for the new signings.

With De Ligt, Branthwaite and Yoro all settling in nicely at Old Trafford, their impact was felt in the Premier League, with Ten Hag's side improving massively in the 2024/25 season. At the end of the campaign, United finished fifth, but it was their defensive record that impressed the most.

20 wins, 13 draws, and five losses saw United end the season on 73 points, 13 more than the previous season, and only seven points off the top four. Ten Hag's side conceded just 31 goals in the league, giving them the joint-best defensive record in the league along with Tottenham.

United earned a spot in the Champions League for the following season in the simulation, but it wasn't to do with finishing fifth. A fantastic European campaign saw Ten Hag's side win the Europa League, with Marcus Rashford scoring twice as United beat Borussia Dortmund 2-1 in the final.

Overall, FM24 predicts that if United can sign Branthwaite, De Ligt and Yoro, their defence could improve drastically, with Ten Hag's side winning a European trophy in the simulation. The triple signing also saw Martinez move into midfield, a switch that definitely worked.

Erik ten Hag's side have secured the signing of Dutch international forward Joshua Zirkzee from Bologna and are closing in on the arrival of teenage defender Leny Yoro from Lille. They have also sold Willy Kambwala to Villarreal, Alvaro Fernandez to Benfica and Donny van de Beek to Girona, while Omari Forson has joined Monza on a free transfer, and Raphael Varane, Anthony Martial, Brandon Williams and Shola Shoretire have also been released.

Mason Greenwood is close to joining Marseille, and Scott McTominay, Aaron Wan-Bissaka and Victor Lindelof have been linked with moves away from Old Trafford as United look to trade more players to fund their transfer overhaul. United have been linked with midfielders Manuel Ugarte and Joao Neves, while they are still in the market for two further centre-halves beyond the Yoro deal.

Personal terms have been agreed with Bayern Munich defender Matthijs De Ligt but they have seen two bids rejected for Everton's Jarrad Branthwaite. Now, Bayer Leverkusen defender Jonathan Tah has emerged as a potential alternative. As such, Manchester Evening News have rounded up everything you need to know about United's pursuit of the German international.

Tah is the club's vice-captain and made 48 appearances in all competitions last term as Leverkusen won an historic first Bundesliga title while going the entire season unbeaten, won the DFB Pokal and reached the final of the Europa League. The 28-year-old is a regular for the German national team, too, and is one of Bayer's core players they want to build their team around as they look to defend their title this term.

However, he is out of contract at the BayArena next summer and he is yet to sign a new deal with the club. Manager Xabi Alonso does not want to lose him but there is an acceptance this transfer window will be the last chance they have to recoup a sizeable fee for the defender.
As such, Leverkusen will not accept anything less than €40million (£33.7million) for the defender they signed for €7.5 million nine years ago.

However, Leverkusen are interested in signing former Liverpool defender Joel Matip on a free transfer this summer. The Cameroon international left Anfield after eight years last month after winning seven major trophies on Merseyside.

The 32-year-old is weighing up his next move and he could be tempted by a return to Germany, with Alonso 'very interested' in securing his services, according to Sky Sports in Germany. Matip previously spent seven years at Schalke 04, helping the club win the DFB Pokal and the DFL-Supercup, as well as reaching the Champions League semi-finals in 2011.

Leverkusen believe Matip's experience will be vital as they bid to defend their German title and navigate the Champions League, which he won with Liverpool, next term. Should that deal go through, it could make Tah's departure more palatable.

United would face competition from German giants Bayern Munich for Tah's signature, though. Reeling from losing their Bundesliga title to Leverkusen, Bayern are keen to take three of their key players from last season to ensure it doesn't happen again.
Josip Stanisic spent last season on loan at the BayArena and he will return to Bavaria this term. They are also keen on signing Leverkusen superstar Florian Wirtz, too.

And they believe they can take advantage of Tah's contract situation by lodging a bid this summer. They are currently €20million short of Bayer's valuation but Tah is believed to be open to a move to the Allianz Arena.

Manchester United have made no secret about their plan to strengthen at centre-back this summer and the main question to answer is which signatures will they eventually secure? Jarrad Branthwaite, Matthijs de Ligt and highly-rated Lille youngster Leny Yoro are on the shopping list for Erik ten Hag and key figures behind the scenes.

However, another man - Bundesliga-winning Bayer Leverkusen colossus Jonathan Tah - has emerged as a possible alternative with the wheels in motion for a defensive rebuild. Reports from Sky Germany underline the 28-year-old as a viable and attainable option on the proviso Branthwaite, De Ligt or Yoro slip away.

Netherlands international De Ligt - well known to manager Ten Hag from their days together at Ajax - has verbally agreed personal terms as he aims to kick-start a promising career that has stalled for club and country. But while he might not break the bank as such, Everton are playing hard ball with Branthwaite's valuation.

It's said the Merseyside outfit are holding out for between £70million and £80million and signing over that cheque, regardless of his talent, might not be the smartest move. Yoro, meanwhile, is claimed to have Real Madrid no other on red alert - as the Branthwaite conundrum flags up an all-too-familiar mistake.

United have been among the worst spenders in world football for at least a decade and, with INEOS on board and controlling transfers, the intention is to pay smart money and make better footballing and business decisions. They were stung in that regard 12 months ago when snapping-up Mason Mount from Chelsea.

That is not to say Mount was not worth signing, nor would Branthwaite be. However, amid lingering FFP caution - which could yet be eased with further sales - spending a huge chunk of the budget on one marquee signing might restrict what else United can do in the market.

INEOS will not want to spread themselves too thinly either by bringing in too many cheap options, but Tah fits the bill for a happy middle ground. He is coming off the back of a hugely impressive and successful season as part of an all-conquering Leverkusen side that earned rave reviews under Xabi Alonso.

Tah was also a regular for Germany at Euro 2024 on home soil - partnering Antonio Rudiger in a back four - while a loophole with his contract has emerged to thrust his name on to the radar. With 12 months to run on his deal -just like Mount had - there are clubs taking note including United and the mighty Bayern Munich.

Even taking 'the English tax' into consideration, United overpaid for Mount at a similar juncture. INEOS, though, will not let that happen with Tah representing an opportunity that should not be missed.

Manchester United began their pre-season schedule by losing 1-0 against Rosenborg.
United have a huge and loyal following in Scandinavia and the Reds played in front of a sold-out Lerkendal Stadium, although the fans in attendance weren't treated to a goal-fest.
That was largely down to Radek Vitek, who delivered a man-of-the-match performance in between the sticks for United to deny Rosenborg a more dominant win on home soil.
The travelling squad at Erik ten Hag's disposal in Trondheim was youthful and just five senior players, Jonny Evans, Aaron Wan-Bissaka, Casemiro, Mason Mount and Marcus Rashford, made the trip.
Those five first-team players were substituted at half-time as wholesale changes were made, which saw Vitek keep his place and 10 youngsters come on.
Vitek made a string of excellent saves throughout the match and will be hopeful of playing against Rangers this weekend. Here are the moments you might have missed...

You could argue Marcus Rashford is currently like Marmite among United supporters: he splits opinion. The forward enjoyed the best campaign of his career in 2022/23 but spectacularly regressed last term and his off-field behaviour damaged his relationship with fans.
Rashford, at least, ended the season with a positive showing in the FA Cup final and many believed missing out on the England squad would allow him to refocus this summer.

There is a lot for Rashford to prove in the new campaign. He must deliver consistently strong displays again and perform to the level he's capable of, otherwise, the 2024/25 season could be his last representing his hometown club and the team he supported as a boy.

There were times when Old Trafford's frustration with Rashford was audible last term, but that didn't stop the crowd in Norway giving his name the biggest cheer when it was announced. Rashford was the biggest 'star' on the pitch in Trondheim and must deliver performances worthy of star status going forward, or his future at the club will be in bigger doubt.

When Hull City played Manchester City at the Etihad in December 2008, they embarrassingly trailed 4-0 after just 36 minutes and their furious manager, Phil Brown, famously made the unusual decision of giving his team talk on the pitch - not in the dressing room - at half-time.
It's a moment in Premier League history that won't be forgotten, mostly because a Hull player subsequently reenacted the team talk in a goal celebration a year later.
Ten Hag did his best impression of Phil Brown at the Lerkendal Stadium on Monday night, as he also decided to conduct his half-time team talk on the pitch during the break.
The Dutchman was seen in deep communication with his players, although with it being a pre-season friendly, he wasn't feeling the emotions Brown once felt at the Etihad.

Nonetheless, Ten Hag was strong in his analysis after the game and said: "The result is not secondary. We play pre-season, but it's the standard at Manchester United to win games - definitely don't lose them. The performance is more important but it was below our standards."
Maybe we'll see Ten Hag's team talk reenacted as a celebration at some stage this season after all.

There was a bizarre quirk before the game when goalkeeper coach Jelle ten Rouwelaar emerged to take the warm-up without his official appointment having been announced. Ten Rouwelaar put the goalkeepers through their paces before kick-off and at 4:17pm, United officially communicated his appointment across their social media channels.

The Dutchman has joined United as first-team goalkeeper coach and succeeds Richard Hartis, who departed this summer. Ten Rouwelaar has been Vincent Kompany's goalkeeping coach for the previous four years, first at Anderlecht and then at Burnley.
He left Turf Moor at the end of his contract and signed a deal with Ajax before United showed an interest, which meant it took €100,000 in compensation to appoint him.

Ten Rouwelaar will work with Andre Onana, Tom Heaton and Altay Bayindir at first-team level this season, but he'll coach Vitek during pre-season and the youngster can be immensely proud of the performance he delivered against Rosenborg on Monday evening.
Vitek is an imposing goalkeeper and will be hopeful of receiving more opportunities in United's friendlies this summer before another departure on loan again.

Interestingly, another Czech goalkeeper, Matej Kovar, impressed for United in pre-season last summer but he was sold to Bayer Leverkusen on a permanent deal. United banked £7.7million for Kovar, who was 23 years old when he left, but Vitek might have a better chance of breaking into the first-team squad in the future.

body: The latest Manchester United news as the forward looks set to move to French club Marseille after impressing on loan with Getafe last season.

The sale of Mason Greenwood this summer looks set to beat a post-Sir Alex Ferguson record for Manchester United with the forward on the verge of leaving Old Trafford.

After being sent on loan to Getafe last season, Greenwood’s performances caught the eye, after he scored eight times and provided six assists in 33 La Liga performances. The Spanish side were keen to sign him on a permanent deal but were unwilling to match United’s asking price.

That prompted interest from several other clubs, including Lazio and Marseille. And it seems like the latter are now closing in on a move for Greenwood with the Athletic reporting that an agreement has been reached with both United and the player over a transfer.

The move was put into doubt following criticism from supporters and the mayor of Marseille. Greenwood was suspended in January 2022 after being arrested for attempted rape, controlling and coercive behaviours and assault, but the case was dropped and all charged were withdrawn.

If the transfer to Marseille is completed, then it will see United earn an initial €27.6 million (£23.3m) with the fee potentially rising to €31.6 million (£26.7m) with add-ons. The profit made, seeing as Greenwood is an academy graduate, will be the most made since the retirement of Ferguson in 2013.

The sale will come as a boost to United in terms of the Premier League’s Profitability and Sustainability Rules (PSRs). Due to him being an academy player, money made will go down as pure profit in the books for the 2024/25 season.

It comes just days after United confirmed the signing of striker Joshua Zirkzee, who completed a move from Bologna for €42.5 million (£35.8m) over the weekend. The Dutchman has signed a five-year deal at Old Trafford with the option of a sixth.

headline: Jarrad Branthwaite to Man United transfer latest - Everton sale decision, bids rejected, £80m tag
body: The latest transfer news from Old Trafford as Man United continue to pursue Everton's Jarrad Branthwaite after having two bids turned down for the England U21s international.
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info

Manchester United and Everton are seemingly worlds apart when it comes to striking up a transfer for defender Jarrad Branthwaite with two offers already being rejected for the England international. United are still weighing-up moves for up to three centre-backs this summer as part of a defensive overhaul.

Matthijs de Ligt and Leny Yoro are the club's two other main targets after rubber-stamping a swoop for Bologna forward Joshua Zirkzee which has accounted for £36.5million in their budget. Getting all three defenders over the line will, meanwhile, be dependant on moving parts including the need for player sales.

Branthwaite, 22, is viewed as an ideal fit for the United rebuild and also worked with returning assistant manager Ruud van Nistelrooy during his successful loan spell with PSV Eindhoven in the 2022/2023 season. Here, we take a closer look at the latest headlines surrounding Branthwaite's future;

Leny Yoro has agreed to sign for Manchester United this summer in a deal that is set to rise to €70million (£58.7m) after Lille accepted a bid of €62million (£52m) earlier this week. The 18-year-old is set to be United's second signing of the summer after Bologna forward Joshua Zirkzee's arrival, and will likely be available to travel with United to Los Angeles for their pre-season tour next week.

Yoro is set to be part of a majorly-revamped defensive line which will see United attempt to patch up the evident holes from last season with three new signings, of which Yoro is one. Everton have already rejected two bids for their centre-back Jarrad Branthwaite while United are on the precipice of signing Bayern Munich star Matthijs De Ligt.
United have had two offers rejected for Branthwaite already this summer. But will it be third time lucky?

The second bid was worth £45million to Everton plus £5million in add-ons. It came after United saw a £43million attempt turned down last month, while Manchester Evening News reported in May that Branthwaite is valued at between £70million and £80million by the Toffeers - which United argue is unrealistic.

Previous deals for Harry Maguire to United (£80million), Wesley Fofana to Chelsea (£75million) and Josko Gvardiol to Manchester City (£77.6million) are viewed as justification for the price tag in Everton's eyes.

Everton have played hard ball from the outset when it comes to Branthwaite and business elsewhere means they do not necessarily have to cash-in on the England international this summer. Amadou Onana is seemingly ready to leave for Aston Villa in an agreement that will generate around £50million for the Toffees.
As such, they can continue to wait for a third, improved bid from United or ultimately hold firm.

Ongoing reports from The Liverpool ECHO and national publications indicate that Everton do not want or need to sell Branthwaite this summer. The 22-year-old remains under contract until 2027 having put pen-to-paper on a new deal at Goodison Park midway through last season.

The party line from Everton hints at business as usual. Branthwaite, who was overlooked for the England squad at Euro 2024 by now-departed national team manager Gareth Southgate this summer, is sharpening up his fitness as Everton head to Ireland to continue their pre-season preparations.
Branthwaite boarded the short flight from John Lennon Airport on Monday morning. As such, no immediate move appears to be on the cards for him - despite United's ongoing interest.

headline: Manchester United player ratings vs Rosenborg as Radek Vitek brilliant and Casemiro sluggish
body: Man Utd began their preparations for the 2024/25 season with a friendly against Norwegian giants Rosenborg at their Lerkendal Stadion home.
Manchester United began their pre-season schedule with a 1-0 defeat against Rosenborg in Norway, with youngsters Ethan Wheatley and Ethan Ennis having the only chances of note for the visitors.

Aaron Wan-Bissaka, Jonny Evans, Casemiro, Mason Mount, Hannibal and Marcus Rashford all played the first 45 minutes at the Lerkendal stadium and they were only the first-team players involved in the fixture.

Erik ten Hag changed his entire outfield team for the second half, with only the impressive Radek Vitek remaining on. Rosenborg are midway through their domestic season and their greater match sharpness was in evidence, with United's goalkeeper denying them on several occasions.

The hosts also hit the woodwork four times before a 92nd-minute winner earned a victory they had probably merited. United now return to Carrington before Saturday's fixture against Rangers at Murrayfield.

Only the most highly regarded talents in the academy are given pre-pro contracts that activate when the player celebrates their 17th birthday and Mantato is included in that bracket.

Manchester United youngster Jack Kingdon has signed his first professional contract with the club.
The Manchester Evening News understands Kingdon has put pen to paper on his first professional deal, which is the reward for his excellent progress in the academy.
Kingdon played a crucial role for the Under-18s last season as they claimed the treble, regularly starting in central defence and wearing the captain's armband on two occasions.

The MEN exclusively revealed Kingdon took part in first-team training for the first time in April. Last season's U18s team were supremely talented and Kingdon made a total of 27 appearances in the academy, going from strength to strength in the club's youth set up.
Kingdon, whose natural position is centre-back, delivered a string of impressive displays and now his pro deal is officially signed, he will attempt to make a senior debut.
Ethan Wheatley was the most recent academy youngster to be given his debut and the expectation inside United is that more debuts from last season's U18 team will follow.
Kingdon's quality helped the U18s concede just 28 league goals last term, the second-fewest in the division behind Manchester City, who conceded 27 goals.
The 18-year-old, who was born in Bolton, started his career with Greater Manchester grassroots club FC Strikerz Avengers before joining Morecambe at Under-12 level.

Kingdon notably made an appearance for Morecambe's U18s when his age group was Under-14 level. United eventually signed the youngster for a six-figure sum in November 2020, following a successful two-week trial period at the club, and he's made excellent progress since joining.

The defender played multiple positions at grassroots level, including as a striker and midfielder, but he's since excelled at centre-back and he's considered very strong, pacy and someone who can read the game well from the back.

Kingdon stands at 6ft 1in and briefly played rugby as a child but wanted to prioritise football. He was also a gifted athlete, as he once took gold medals in the 75m, 150m and 600m sprints at the Bolton United Harriers championships.
He has represented Scotland, whom he qualifies to represent through his father, at different youth levels and has worn the captain's armband for his country.

headline: Man United 'rejected' chance to sign £60m Arsenal target for next to nothing

Manchester United are said to have missed out on the chance to sign Arsenal target Pedro Neto for next to nothing.

The Gunners have long admired the Wolverhampton Wanderers winger and could finalise a £60million deal for the 24-year-old this summer. The Portuguese star joined Wolves in 2019 from Braga, following a loan spell at Lazio. However, before his move to Italy, United were believed to be closely monitoring the promising attacker.

According to The Athletic, United identified Neto in early 2017 and even invited the then-teenager to Carrington. Despite impressing coaches and scouts during an academy game, it took too long for a contract to be sanctioned, it is claimed, leading Neto to sign a new deal with Braga before joining Lazio on a long-term loan.

He later moved to Wolves in 2019 and made his senior international debut a year later. The hesitation is consistent with claims from former club scouts, who say they discovered talents, only for the club to not act quickly enough to tie them down.

The Red Devils were also said to have identified current Bayern Munich and Germany star Jamal Musial and Moises Caicedo, now of Chelsea, early in their development. Lyndon Tomlinson, who served as the assistant head of academy recruitment at United from 2017 to 2021, told The Athletic: "I think it's just being decisive and getting things over the line, that was always the problem.
"In terms of the scouting, the structure and system we had - look at [Alejandro] Garnacho - was good. The reports were there, the process was there. We were just being let down at the end of it.

"That's why I left, ultimately. I was getting frustrated that we were doing reports, I was travelling here, there and everywhere, [and] studying lots of video during Covid. We were making recommendations and then there was just nothing really happening."

headline: Major Man United appointment could spell good news for women's team after nightmare week
body: It's been a turbulent week for Manchester United Women but the arrival of Dan Ashworth could be exactly what they need to get back on track
Our community members are treated to special offers, promotions and adverts from us and our partners. You can check out at any time. More info
Though Mary Earps' Manchester United goodbye message totaled 370 words, perhaps the biggest factor behind her decision to leave the club can be gleaned from just one: 'Transition'.

Those 10 measly characters, deployed by Earps to describe the current state of play at Leigh Sports Village, rather concisely explain why one of the game's biggest stars feels the best thing for her career is to seek pastures new this summer. The 31-year-old's departure did not, admittedly, come as much of a surprise.

Hers is an exit almost 12 months in the making, the portent of which can be traced back to Arsenal's failed world-record bid for her services last September. Still, though, in conjunction with a number of other happenings at United over the past few weeks, confirmation of Earps' leaving has been viewed in some quarters as an ominous indicator of the Reds' direction of travel.

"It's a decision l've gone backwards and forwards on for some time, and is not one I've made lightly," the England No. 1 wrote on social media on Saturday. "The club is about to undergo a period of transition, and unfortunately I don't feel it aligns with the timing of where I'm at in my career, therefore I think now is the right time to make a change and embark on a new challenge."

That new challenge is set to take Earps to the French capital, where she will become the highest-paid women's goalkeeper in the world for Paris Saint-Germain (PSG). It is understood, however, United's offer of a new deal matched Earps' expectations and therefore her decision to leave the club is rooted not in finances but in a desire to be successful on the pitch.

Clearly, the shot-stopper remains unconvinced about the Reds' ability to yield such success in the near future. Despite winning the Women's FA Cup - the club's first major piece of women's silverware - last term, it's hard to argue with the fact that United's performances in 2023/24 left much to be desired.

Marc Skinner's side finished fifth in the Women's Super League (WSL), winning just 10 of their 22 league games and registering a points tally 21 points lower than the one recorded in the previous campaign. A 6-0 defeat to champions Chelsea at Old Trafford on the final day was a crushing nadir for a team who had taken the title race to the final day only 12 months earlier, and the travelling support took great pleasure in making Earps the chief subject of their derision, regularly taunting her with chants of 'Mary, what's the score?'

There is an argument, though, that United's malaise on the field is a symptom of the pervasive uncertainty off it. It has been a turbulent year for the Reds, who came under fire last summer for letting star duo Ona Batlle and Alessia Russo depart on free transfers, with the latter joining WSL rivals Arsenal.

Then there was the Mason Greenwood debacle, which opened a number of female players up to online abuse on the eve of decisive Women's World Cup games. Couple this with the departure of numerous backroom staff, including highly-rated assistant manager Martin Ho and head of women's football Polly Bancroft, and it is easy to see why some players may feel United is, at present, a club in flux.

Those feelings have only intensified since the arrival of Sir Jim Ratcliffe in February. The INEOS chief caused a stir when he opted not to attend the Women's FA Cup final in May, instead making an appearance at Old Trafford for what was, for the hosts, something of a dead-rubber Premier League clash with Arsenal.

Days later came confirmation of a new contract for manager Skinner - a decision that was not particularly well-received by the United fanbase, in spite of the FA Cup triumph. And then there was last week, when it seemed as if every day brought with it a new PR fire for the Reds to put out.

First, there was Ratcliffe's tone-deaf interview with Bloomberg, in which he conceded plans for the women's team were "TBC". Next came the revelation that Skinner's side are set to be ousted from their state-of-the-art Carrington training facility to make way for the men's team while their own building gets a revamp - and that's before you consider the exodus of first-team stars, including Earps and club captain Katie Zelem.

Cue the emergence of reports citing concern from the Professional Footballers Association (PFA) and of agents' apparent unwillingness to throw their players into the maelstrom that is Manchester United; a dangerous cocktail of bad news that does not inspire much hope of positive change at the club.

Still, amidst all the negativity, there are green shoots of optimism. According to BBC Sport, United are closing in on deals to sign Brighton & Hove Albion forward Elisabeth Terland and former Arsenal defender Dominique Janssen.

The duo are at opposite ends of the experience spectrum but could both have a hugely positive impact at Leigh Sports Village. Terland scored 13 goals in the WSL last term, with only Manchester City's Khadija Shaw finding the back of the net more frequently than the 23-year-old.

Janssen, meanwhile, has won two league titles and starred in two Champions League finals for German side Wolfsburg, having previously won the WSL with the Gunners. United are also expected to trigger the option-to-buy clause in the loan agreement of highly-rated Lyon forward, Melvine Malard.

With midfielder Grace Clinton set to return to Manchester following a hugely successful loan spell at Tottenham Hotspur and the likes of Gabby George and Hinata Miyazawa expected to play a bigger role following their respective returns to full fitness, the Reds look to have have the makings of a strong squad.

Perhaps one of the most heartening developments for the women's team, though, came on Monday morning, when it emerged sporting director Dan Ashworth is free to begin work at United after breakthrough talks with former club Newcastle. The two clubs have come to an agreement over compensation after an acrimonious four months of talks, avoiding the need for an arbitration hearing to settle the matter.

While Ashworth's priority will almost certainly be changing the fortunes of Erik Ten Hag's side, the 53-year-old has long been an advocate for investing in women's football and could be the spark United require to reignite their commitment to Skinner and his players. Speaking to the Guardian in 2022, Ashworth outlined the club's vision for Newcastle Women, who were, at the time, plying their trade in the fourth tier.

"(The women's team) is absolutely a priority for the owners,” he said. “Already, they’ve gone from a team where the players had to pay to play last year to being professionalised. We will do everything we can to give them the support to get to the WSL as quickly as possible.”

His comments were reminiscent of a similar statement he made during his time as technical director of Brighton & Hove Albion. “The aim now is to get a foothold in the top division, being a new club and new women’s programme compared to some of the teams in that division," Ashworth told club media back in 2019.

“We aim to do that by maximising our resources, trying to recruit cleverly, coach well and get the results to keep us in the division. It comes back to the club’s long-term vision, which is to make us a top four women’s team. It will take time, effort and investment to do that, but we’re on the right lines to do it.”

By joining United, Ashworth is joining a club with significantly more resources than Brighton and with a bigger global brand than Newcastle. If he is able to lend some of his expertise to Skinner's side, there is a chance the Reds could soon find themselves back on the right path and their period of transition might just lead them into a brighter new era.

headline: PSG confirm Mary Earps transfer after Manchester United decision
body: Earps has joined PSG on a free transfer, having turned down the chance to sign a new deal at Leigh Sports Village

Paris Saint-Germain have confirmed the signing of England goalkeeper Mary Earps on a free transfer.

The 31-year-old joins the French giants following the expiry of her Manchester United contract, having turned down the chance to sign a new deal at Leigh Sports Village. She is set to become the highest-paid women's goalkeeper in the world at PSG and has signed a two-year contract that will keep her at the club until the summer of 2026.
"I'm very honoured to become a Parisian and I can't wait to play alongside my new team-mates," Earps said. "Together, we're going to give our all to help the club shine and make our fans proud.
"I'm determined to contribute to our future success so that Paris St-Germain continues to rank among Europe's top clubs."
PSG finished second in Division 1 Féminine last term and reached the semi-finals of the Champions League while United finished fifth in the Women's Super League (WSL) and won the Women's FA Cup.

Earps, who has twice been named the FIFA Best Goalkeeper, joins a number of high-profile players leaving United on free transfers in this summer. Last week, the club confirmed captain Katie Zelem and forward Lucia Garcia were also set to leave Manchester following the expiration of their contracts.

Reflecting on her decision to leave United in a social media post on Saturday, Earps said: "It's a decision I've gone backwards and forwards on for some time, and is not one I've made lightly. The club is about to undergo a period of transition, and unfortunately I don't feel it aligns with the timing of where I'm at in my career, therefore I think now is the right time to make a change and embark on a new challenge.
"There aren't the right words, or enough words, to express my heartfelt gratitude to you all, but I hope the below comes somewhere close."
